item.title: Ban Ki-moon: 'World living in an era of unprecedented level of crises'
item.description:
UN secretary general prepares to welcome more than 140 heads of state to organisation's general assembly this week

More than 140 heads of state and government fly in to New York this week for the United Nations general assembly amid apprehension that international order is unraveling at an accelerating pace, while the world's leaders seem ever less willing or able to deal with the proliferating threats.

The UN's humanitarian agencies are in danger of being completely overwhelmed by the multiple crises. Ebola is spreading rapidly across West Africa, swamping rickety national health systems and a thus-far underfunded UN effort to stop its advance. The spread of Islamic State (Isis) extremists in the Middle East, feeding on the destruction of the Syrian civil war and exposing the weakness of the Iraqi state, has similarly outpaced patchy international efforts at containment.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: United Nations secretary general Ban Ki-moon with actor Leonardo DiCaprio during his designation ceremony as the UN Messenger of Peace. Photograph: EPA
United Nations secretary general Ban Ki-moon with actor Leonardo DiCaprio during his designation ceremony as the UN Messenger of Peace. Photograph: EPA

item.dc:creator: Julian Borger, diplomatic editor in New York

item.title: The Iraqi town where former foes are combining to fight Islamic State
item.description:
Sunnis uniting with Shias in Thuluyah as tribal leaders point to example of how war against Isis Islamic militants can be won

The metal-hulled boats carry out the wounded for treatment, as well as fruit to sell at market. They bring in supplies of cooking gas, medicine and ammunition.

Cocooned in a bend in the Tigris river, this town shaded by orange trees and date palm groves has long relied on the waterway. But since Islamic State (Isis) militants blew up the last bridge into Thuluyah earlier this month, the river is the only way in or out complicating efforts to resupply and reinforce beleaguered fighters here.

Continue reading...

Unloading produce on the banks of the Tigris,Thuluyah, Iraq.
A boatman drives from the besieged town of Thuluyah, Iraq. Photograph: Loveday Morris/Washington Post
A boatman drives from the besieged town of Thuluyah, Iraq. Photograph: Loveday Morris/Washington Post

item.dc:creator: Loveday Morris in Thuluyah for the Washington Post

item.title: Germanys Eurosceptics broaden their appeal and win regional votes
item.description:
The right-wing Alternative for Germany party has built on its support to make gains in Saxony, Brandenburg and Thuringia

The rise of the Alternative for Germany (AfD) party continued with it receiving 10.6% of the vote in Thuringia and 12.2% in Brandenburg on 14 September. Two weeks earlier it secured its first regional government seats in Saxony.

This new conservative party is beginning to gain ground. The AfD was founded 18 months ago, by former Christian Democratic Union militants and sympathisers disappointed by Chancellor Angela Merkels shift towards the centre.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: Bernd Lucke, 52, the founder and main spokesman of the Alternative for Germany party (AfD). Photograph: Tobias Schwarz/AFP/Getty Images
Bernd Lucke, 52, the founder and main spokesman of the Alternative for Germany party (AfD). Photograph: Tobias Schwarz/AFP/Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Frédéric Lemaître

item.title: Inside the 26 September edition
item.description:
After the Scottish referendum; UN surveys the wreckage; the history of emoticons

So, it was a No. Scotland may have voted to stay in the United Kingdom last week but the 45% of Scots who endorsed independence are still likely to have laid the foundations for extensive power devolution in the UK. With a sudden revival of popular interest in how the nation is governed, it feels like the British political system is under the microscope like never before.

In this weeks GW we bring you a special package on the aftermath of the independence referendum, as writers including Scottish author Irvine Welsh and regular columnists Jonathan Freedland and Timothy Garton Ash pick over the future of the union and the roadmap to a more inclusive and relevant system of representation. I promise that you wont find sharper, more passionate and more insightful writing on the subject anywhere else.

Continue reading...

item.dc:creator: Graham Snowdon

item.title: Good to meet you ... Keith Openshaw
item.description:
This reader from a Manchester Guardian family travelled the world with the Weekly in hot pursuit

I was born into a Guardian family. In the 1930s my mother was a cook in the Manchester Guardian canteen in Cross Street. She occasionally returned to see former friends and often talked about the reporters she knew as well as CP Scott. Her youngest sister retired from the subscription department in 1978 after 43 years of service. My cousin helped print the Manchester Guardian for a similar number of years.

In 1968 I started subscribing to the Weekly when I moved overseas, first to Tanzania and then to Thailand. In September 1975, I returned to Tanzania for a five-year university teaching assignment. I then moved across the border to Kenya for seven years, first with a Kenyan energy project and later with an USAid regional renewable energy project for eastern and southern Africa.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: Good to meet you Keith Openshaw

item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Guardian Weekly letters, 26 September 2014
item.description:
A world without debt; the funding of politics; Queen and country

In his article Europes economic nightmare approaches (12 September), Paul Mason bases his analysis on the theory that over-indebtedness leads to deflation. However, the very term over-indebtedness makes no sense in 2014 where, as finally made explicit by the Bank of England in the article Money creation in the modern economy (in their 2014 Q1 Quarterly Bulletin), the vast majority of all money is created as debt by commercial banks making loans. In short, if the economy grows, that means more debt has been created. Reduce the amount of debt, and by definition theres less money in the economy. Pay off all debt, and the economy will be left with no money in it. In this scenario, how much debt is too much debt?

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: Illustration by Gary Kempston
Illustration by Gary Kempston

item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Letter from Australia: Point to point
item.description:
Relative isolation is no barrier to community in the small towns of rural Queensland

Its 6am on a winters morning: mist is rising off the lake, and the kookaburras laugh in a nearby gum, challenging the laggards to get up and enjoy yet another sunny day in the low-to-mid-20s. Thats 20C, not your Pommy 20 Fahrenheit it never gets that cold here.

We turn over in bed. No need for us oldies to get up just yet, though our friendly juvenile whip-bird has now joined the morning chorus, lulling us back to sleep.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: The morning call of the kookaburras kickstart another relaxing day in Boreen Point Photograph: Russell Mcphedran/AP
The morning call of the kookaburras kickstart another relaxing day in Boreen Point Photograph: Russell Mcphedran/AP

item.dc:creator: Noel Bird

item.title: Five-star Leicester City bypass Manchester Uniteds glittering attack
item.description:
Lewis Hamilton wins Singapore Grand Prix; Durham crowned one-day champions at Lords; Ana Ivanovic clinches Pan Pacific Open

With $260m of new attacking talent at their disposal, it was no surprise that Manchester United scored three goals at Premier League new boys Leicester City. What was less foreseeable was that they would concede five, much to the irritation of their increasingly red-faced coach Louis van Gaal. You cannot win a game any more when you do that, he said, a judgment that was hard to find fault with. At the Etihad stadium, Frank Lampard popped up with a late equaliser for Manchester City against former club Chelsea as two of this seasons likely title challengers cancelled each other out. In Spain there were big wins for the big two, Barcelona thrashing Levante 5-0 and Real Madrid making that effort look restrained with an 8-2 dismantling of Deportivo La Coruña.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: An increasingly red-faced Louis van Gaal during the Barclays Premier League match between Leicester City and Manchester United. Photograph: Getty
An increasingly red-faced Louis van Gaal during the Barclays Premier League match between Leicester City and Manchester United. Photograph: Getty

item.title: Intelligence is not always appreciated
item.description:
A mixed blessing; Notes & Queries; chopsticks and flavour

Is intelligence a blessing?

For a fortunate individual, often a blessing; for a state, frequently a curse.
Philip Stigger, Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada

Continue reading...

item.dc:creator: Guardian Staff

item.title: Radio-tagging sheep will spell the death of the old ways, say French farmers
item.description:
Farmers question effectiveness of scheme against outbreaks of disease and fear it risks industrialising traditional methods

When it comes to protest, French farmers are hardly known for their reticence. Nothing draws them out into the streets or, as recently, its art galleries quite like a good European Union agricultural policy dispute. But a demonstration held in May by around 50 sheep farmers outside the Tribunal Administratif (which hears civil disputes) in Grenoble, in the south-east, hinged on a relatively new EU gripe: the rules around microchipping livestock.

Etienne Mabille and Irène Bordel, both in their 50s and well tanned by years on the mountain pasture, raise 57 ewes organically at Mévouillon, in nearby Drôme. In April 2012 their farm was inspected. All their animals were tagged and the stock book was up to date. But the couple refused to duplicate the identification system with a second tag containing a computer chip. The inspectors reported this as an anomaly. The following August the regional authorities told them they would no longer qualify for EU subsidies and must pay a heavy fine. This was a severe blow for the small farm so they went to court. The farmers won the first round, but the case is still open.

Continue reading...
item.category: Court of justice of the European Union

item.dc:creator: Sandrine Berthaud-Clair

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy sets out comeback plans for France's UMP party on TV
item.description:
Former president says he wants to get his 'political family back to work' after announcing he will return to frontline politics

The former French president Nicolas Sarkozy was given a prime-time television news slot to explain his plans after announcing his return to frontline politics. Sarkozy set out his platform for the race to head the opposition UMP party, which will hold a hotly contested leadership vote in November.

For Sarkozy: The Return Part II, he was given 45 minutes to reintroduce himself to the French public.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy said he was a new man after having time to 'reflect' after his election defeat in 2012. Photograph: Valery Hache/AFP/Getty Images
Nicolas Sarkozy said he was a new man after having time to 'reflect' after his election defeat in 2012. Photograph: Valery Hache/AFP/Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Kim Willsher in Paris

item.title: Afghanistan power-sharing deal ends months of political gridlock
item.description:
Reformist Ashraf Ghani will become president, while his rival Abdullah Abdullah will be able to fill new role of chief executive

Ashraf Ghani, a former World Bank economist, has been officially declared the new president of Afghanistan, after three months of political deadlock was resolved through a new, untested power-sharing arrangement with his arch rival.

Ghani signed the agreement with Abdullah Abdullah, his adversary in presidential elections in June that left the country suspended in acrimony, fraud allegations and political paralysis. Under the deal, Ghani will run the cabinet and be in charge of strategic functions, while Abdullah will be able to appoint a "chief executive" who will be in charge of daily duties.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: Afghanistan's presidential election candidates Abdullah Abdullah, left, and Ashraf Ghani shake hands at the signing of their power-sharing deal. Photograph: Massoud Hossaini/AP
Afghanistan's presidential election candidates Abdullah Abdullah, left, and Ashraf Ghani shake hands at the signing of their power-sharing deal. Photograph: Massoud Hossaini/AP

item.dc:creator: May Jeong in Kabul

item.title: Teenage peace activists among dead in Libya 'black Friday'
item.description:
Militants assassinate rights workers and army officers while mystery jets launch raids on Tripoli

Two popular young peace activists were among ten prominent Libyan civil rights workers and senior army officers assassinated in the eastern city of Benghazi on Friday, a day that has swiftly become known as Black Friday.

The coordinated killings, a vivid demonstration of the power of militants, took place at a time when the country is in chaos: an Islamist-led coalition is holding Tripoli and the UN has reported that 250,000 have fled the fighting.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: A wave of assassinations in Benghazi has led to the day last week on which they happened being dubbed 'Black Friday'. Photograph: Abdullah Doma/AFP/Getty Images
A wave of assassinations in Benghazi has led to the day last week on which they happened being dubbed 'Black Friday'. Photograph: Abdullah Doma/AFP/Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Chris Stephen

item.title: New Zealand election: party over for Kim Dotcom as PM wins with landslide
item.description:
John Key wins third term, as alliance between Kim Dotcom and the Maori Mana Movement fails to win a single seat

In the 32 months since the ostentatious FBI-backed raid on Kim Dotcom's opulent home north of Auckland, the German émigré has become an integral, irrepressible and unavoidable force in New Zealand politics.

Undaunted by US attempts to extradite him to face charges stemming from alleged copyright breaches by his Megaupload website, Dotcom mounted a vigorous counterattack, both in the courts and the public square, ultimately leading to the resignation of two ministers of the crown and a seething feud with the prime minister, John Key.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: New Zealand's prime minister John Key speaks after being elected to a third term. Photograph: Ross Setford/EPA
New Zealand's prime minister John Key speaks after being elected to a third term. Photograph: Ross Setford/EPA

item.dc:creator: Toby Manhire in Auckland

item.title: Catalonia's parliament paves the way for November vote on independence
item.description:
Catalan leader denies Scotland's referendum result is a setback as Spain's PM says vote planned for November will be illegal

The Catalan parliament passed a law paving the way for a non-binding vote on secession on Friday, hours after finding out it would not have a Scottish precedent to follow in the region's quest for independence.

While noting he would have preferred a yes vote in the Scottish referendum, the Catalan President, Artur Mas, said the task of independence would now be left to Catalonia: "Maybe the first case will be the Catalan one."

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: Catalonia's president Artur Mas gestures after the parliament approved a regional consultation law in Barcelona. Photograph: Gustau Nacarino/REUTERS
Catalonia's president Artur Mas gestures after the parliament approved a regional consultation law in Barcelona. Photograph: Gustau Nacarino/REUTERS

item.dc:creator: Ashifa Kassam in Barcelona

item.title: New Cambridge students to attend compulsory sexual consent workshops
item.description:
Oxford will also put on similar sessions designed to debunk myths surrounding consent at 20 of its colleges

As freshers arrive at Cambridge University next month, on their packed timetable of welcome meetings, matriculation photographs, punting trips and city tours there will be one extra date for their diaries.

For the first time in the university's 800-year history, new undergraduates at half of the colleges will be expected to attend compulsory sexual consent workshops.

Continue reading...

item.dc:creator: Sally Weale, education correspondent

item.title: Sierra Leone begins three-day shutdown to contain Ebola outbreak
item.description:
Six million confined to their homes with only essential workers exempt, while volunteers go door to door handing out soap

Some 6 million residents in Sierra Leone hunkered down at home on Friday as the country began a three-day lockdown aimed at raising awareness about the deadly Ebola virus.

The normally crowded streets were empty in the hilly capital, Freetown, with only security officials and essential workers with government passes allowed out. "Freetown is looking very lonely. We are all just staying at home waiting," said taxi driver Salifu Conte.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: People out to buy last-minute provisions in Freetown on Thursday before the three-day curfew began. Photograph: Tanya Bindra/EPA
People out to buy last-minute provisions in Freetown on Thursday before the three-day curfew began. Photograph: Tanya Bindra/EPA

item.dc:creator: Monica Mark, west Africa Correspondent

item.title: Baltic states wary as Russia takes more strident tone with neighbours
item.description:
Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, anxious that battle of wits with Kremlin may escalate, look to Nato for back-up pledge

The 23rd floor of the Hotel Viru in Tallinn has been carefully preserved as a reminder of Estonia's past. Like much else in the Soviet era, it did not officially exist even though everyone knew it was there. It was where the KGB sat every day and night to eavesdrop on the conversations of the hotel's mostly foreign guests. It remains today as it was when the Soviet spies hastily evacuated at Estonian independence 23 years ago, leaving their listening equipment behind them.

The tone of the guide is jaunty, joking that guests found it quicker to get the minibar replenished by talking loudly to the table lamp than by calling room service. The clunky equipment and cold war paranoia all seems absurd and dated now, but although the KGB fled the Viru, it never altogether left Estonia. Its successor, the Federal Security Bureau (FSB), has remained highly active in Estonia and its Baltic neighbours, Latvia and Lithuania increasingly so recently as Russia seeks to reassert its sway over what it calls the "near abroad".

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: A Stalin monument in Grtas park, Druskininkai, recalls Lithuania's past as a Soviet republic. Photograph: Alamy
A Stalin monument in Grtas park, Druskininkai, recalls Lithuania's past as a Soviet republic. Photograph: Alamy

item.dc:creator: Julian Borger in Tallinn Luke Harding in Kiev

item.title: European fruit growers bruised by Russian sanctions
item.description:
Moscow's tit-for-tat ban on imports of fruits and vegetables over Ukraine crisis leaves EU producers facing bleak autumn

When Russia banned imports of Polish apples in July, politicians and the public laughed off the move by posing with the forbidden fruit on Twitter. Everyone from the head of the national security bureau to TV presenters posted gleeful photos, making the "Eat apples to annoy Putin" campaign a social media hit.

Six weeks later, after the Kremlin extended its ban to all European fresh produce, from Greek peaches to German gherkins and Lithuanian cauliflowers, eating apples as a political statement is wearing thin. "In the beginning there was a slight growth in consumption, but now it has gone back to normal," says Jolanta Kazimierska, head of the Polish Fruit Union.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: A farm worker harvests apples at the Verger d'Epinoy near Cambrai, France. Photograph: Pascal Rossignol/Reuters
A farm worker harvests apples at the Verger d'Epinoy near Cambrai, France. Photograph: Pascal Rossignol/Reuters

item.dc:creator: Jennifer Rankin

item.title: India and China announce trade deals during Xi visit to Delhi
item.description:
China to invest billions in railways, industrial parks and perhaps nuclear power, but experts say amount is less than expected

India and China have announced a series of deals aimed at boosting economic growth in both countries.

Xi Jinping, the Chinese president, said on a visit to Delhi that China would invest billions of dollars over the next five years in railways, industrial parks and, potentially, nuclear power in India.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi in Delhi. Photograph: Raveendran/AFP/Getty Images
Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi in Delhi. Photograph: Raveendran/AFP/Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Jason Burke in Delhi

item.title: Russia, Ukraine and Europe have been into Vladimir Putin's black hole of fear
item.description:
The formula for saving any dictatorship is universal: create an enemy, start a war. We are back in Soviet times of total lies
-

I remember that as a child I read about black holes in a popular science magazine about space and it scared me. The idea of our world being sucked into these breaks in the universe kept bothering me until I realised that it all was so far away that it would not reach us. But then a black hole tore our world very close to us. It started sucking in houses, roads, cars, planes, people and whole countries. Russia and Ukraine have already fallen into this black hole. And it is now sucking in Europe in front of our eyes.

This hole in the universe is the soul of one very lonely ageing man. The black hole is his fear.

Continue reading...

media:content.media:description: Russia's President Vladimir Putin. Photograph: ALEXEY DRUGINYN / RIA NOVOSTI //EPA
Russia's President Vladimir Putin. Photograph: ALEXEY DRUGINYN / RIA NOVOSTI //EPA
